steps.title: March in place on every beat.
steps.content: March in place on every beat. [1] X Expert Source Andrey Stanev Professional Dance Instructor Expert Interview. 20 May 2020. If you’re following, start marching with your right foot. If you’re leading, start marching with your left. For every count of the beat, march 1 step. [2] X Research source You don’t need to pick your feet up very high—about 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) is all you need to march in place.

steps.title: Bend both knees slightly as you pick your feet up.
steps.content: Bend both knees slightly as you pick your feet up. To give yourself a little bounce, keep your knees bent as you make each movement. Try not to lock your knees up, or you might look stiff. The merengue is all about fluid, even motion. [3] X Research source Keeping your knees bent will also help you keep your steps going in one fluid motion.

steps.title: Shift your weight to the foot you’re stepping down on.
steps.content: Shift your weight to the foot you’re stepping down on. For each step that you take, naturally let your hip fall down in time with your feet as you shift your weight. You don't need an excessive hip shaking or gyrating—just that natural hip movement that takes place when you shift weight. [4] X Research source Your hips may move slightly up and down as you sway back and forth. This motion will come naturally to you as you practice the movements more.

steps.title: Listen to merengue music to feel the rhythm.
steps.content: Listen to merengue music to feel the rhythm. Merengue music is all in 4/4 time, so it’s easy to apply to almost any song. Fernando Villalona, Juan Luis Guerra, Eddy Herrera, and Toño Rosario are all artists with great merengue music you can listen to and practice with. [5] X Research source You can also find merengue mixes on YouTube with hours and hours of songs playing continuously.

steps.title: Face your partner and stand about 3 inches (7.6 cm) apart.
steps.content: Face your partner and stand about 3 inches (7.6 cm) apart. The merengue is a pretty intimate dance, so you’ll want to start out with someone you know pretty well. Start by facing each other and then move in closer so there isn’t much distance between the two of you. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Put your hand on your partner’s shoulder blade.
steps.content: Put your hand on your partner’s shoulder blade. Lift both of your arms up to about shoulder-height. If you’re the leader, put your right hand on your partner’s left shoulder blade, and if you’re the follower, put your left hand on your partner’s right shoulder blade. [7] X Expert Source Andrey Stanev Professional Dance Instructor Expert Interview. 20 May 2020. This is also called closed dance position. [8] X Expert Source Andrey Stanev Professional Dance Instructor Expert Interview. 20 May 2020.

steps.title: Grab your partner’s free hand with your other hand.
steps.content: Grab your partner’s free hand with your other hand. Now, put your free arm up in an L shape at about shoulder-height. Grasp your partner’s free hand in yours for a secure hold. [9] X Expert Source Andrey Stanev Professional Dance Instructor Expert Interview. 20 May 2020. If you’re the leading partner, you’ll raise your left hand. If you’re the follower, you’ll raise your right hand.

steps.title: Travel across the floor in a circle.
steps.content: Travel across the floor in a circle. [10] X Expert Source Andrey Stanev Professional Dance Instructor Expert Interview. 20 May 2020. With this basic marching step, start moving back and forth, left and right. If you’re the leading partner, rotate slowly in a 360 degree turn. Take a full 8 beats to do the turn, and try not to rush your movements. [11] X Research source If you’re feeling groovy, take 16 counts to do the turn instead of 8.

steps.title: Try a one-handed turn.
steps.content: Try a one-handed turn. While doing the basic steps, grab both of your partner’s hands in your own. If you’re the leading partner, keep one hand clasped and lift the other one in the air, letting your partner turn either inside or outside of their own arm. If you’re the follower, keep one hand on your partner’s and spin underneath your own arm in one direction. [12] X Research source Keep the basic step going the entire time! Turn at the same pace you're stepping: a casual 1, 2, 3, 4.

steps.title: Add in two-handed turns.
steps.content: Add in two-handed turns. Slide out into the same open position you would for one-handed turns, and, this time, lift both hands up into the air. If you’re the following partner, go under both of your arms in a 360 degree turn, ending with your arms crossed. To uncross your arms, turn back around in the opposite direction. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Do the hammerlock turn.
steps.content: Do the hammerlock turn. If you’re the leading partner, raise one hand up in the air and turn your partner to the outside. If you’re the following partner, wrap one of your arms behind your back and keep one arm out. This will put you directly next to your partner so you’re side-by-side. If you’re the leading partner, put your free hand on your partner’s hip. [14] X Research source If you'd like, keep that momentum and turn in a slow, 360 degree circle. Then, unwind the following partner by taking their free hand and spinning her back the other direction, resuming a normal stance.

steps.title: Add in a cuddle turn.
steps.content: Add in a cuddle turn. If you’re the leader, raise one hand up in the air and turn your partner to the inside. If you’re the follower, wrap both of your arms around yourself and stand directly in front of your partner. Next, if you’re the leading partner, move your partner to the side and stand hip to hip with them. [15] X Research source You can take your momentum to move around in a circle, with the following partner going backwards.
